awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: RUI: Synthesis of Robust Artificial Systems by Adaptive Genetic Programming
awd_abstract_narration:
Computer-based problem-solving systems are revolutionizing many areas of science and engineering, with pervasive impacts on economic activity, human health, national security, and the advancement of science. Several of the most powerful and promising approaches to the development of these systems borrow ideas from biology, for example, when artificial neural networks are used to enable computer systems to learn. The processes of random variation and fitness-based selection motivated by biology have been particularly useful in several applications, but they have not yet produced the kind of radical innovations that are characteristic of living systems. In this project, key elements of genetic programming, such as the processes governing variation, will themselves be allowed to adapt, with the aim of producing more powerful problem-solving computer systems. These systems may have applications in several areas of science and engineering. The project will be conducted in the context of educational activities that integrate research and education across undergraduate and graduate levels, thereby providing training to a new generation of computational scientists.
 
The primary goal of the proposed project is to enhance genetic programming technologies in ways that will allow them to more routinely produce more innovative solutions to difficult problems, and to produce systems that perform well in complex environments. The central hypothesis underlying this effort is that the innovating power of biology, and the power of biology to produce robust systems, stems in part from the fact that the adaptive mechanisms of biology themselves adapt. Self-adaptive genetic programming systems, in which the algorithms for variation and selection are themselves subject to variation and selection, have been explored for decades but have only recently begun to show practical promise for solving difficult problems. The proposed project will begin with a promising system of this type and will test it systematically, in order to elucidate general principles that will then be used to develop and apply more refined, adaptive algorithms. Applications ranging from the automatic programming of exercises in a first-semester programming textbook to the development of multicellular organisms in a virtual ecosystem will be used to test and demonstrate the systems developed in this project.

por.por_cntn:
This project involved the development, testing, and application of improvements to evolutionary computation techniques. These techniques use ideas from biological evolution, including random variation and selection, to solve computational problems. Investigated by researchers for several decades, such systems have recently proven capable of solving problems of theoretical and practical significance. In this project, enhancements were developed to allow these systems to more routinely produce solutions to difficult problems.

The hypothesis underlying this effort was that the power of biological evolution stems from the fact that evolutionary processes themselves adapt over time. Self-adaptive evolutionary computation systems, in which the algorithms for variation and/or selection adapt over the course of evolution, had been explored previously but had only recently begun to show promise for solving difficult problems. Work on this project began with an investigation of the most promising prior systems, testing them systematically, in order to elucidate general principles of self-adaptive evolutionary computation. The lessons from these analyses were then used to develop more capable algorithms.

The systems studied in this project were tested on benchmark problems that ranged from "software synthesis" problems, in which the goal is to automate routine programming tasks, to image recognition and robot control problems. Standard benchmarks were used when they were available, and new benchmarks were developed when they were not. The software synthesis benchmark problems developed by the PI's group and used in this project have since been used by other research groups to investigate other techniques.

Among the specific innovations developed in this project were a new variation method and several new parent selection methods, which are used to select the candidate solutions from which variants will be produced.

The new variation method ("UMAD," for Uniform Mutation by Addition and Deletion) was suggested by results from a system in which variation methods evolved. UMAD is similar to the widely used "point mutation" method, except that instead of replacing an old gene with a new gene, which is normally done by deleting one gene and then adding a new gene in its place, it separates the addition and deletion steps so that they may affect different parts of the genome. This simple change, found by a self-adaptive evolutionary process, can be used in any system with variable-length genomes, and has been shown to significantly improve the problem-solving power of evolutionary computation systems in several contexts.

Many of the new parent selection methods developed in this project are enhancements of the "lexicase" selection algorithm. In most prior evolutionary computation systems, parents are selected on the basis of their performance over a set of test cases, with the results of individual test cases aggregated to produce a single numerical score of a potential parent's quality. In lexicase selection, by contrast, test cases are considered separately, in random sequences, in a winnowing process that selects parents from which offspring will be produced. Lexicase selection had previously been shown to out-perform aggregating parent selection methods in several respects, and in this project the reasons for this were investigated and exploited to produce even more successful methods. One of the lessons from this work is that it is helpful to select "specialists," which excel in some ways but may be weak in others. Another is that because lexicase selection rewards good performance relative to the rest of the population on single tests and combinations of tests, it promotes adaptation at a finer level of granularity than prior systems. This helps to explain the unusual combination of high diversity and problem-solving success observed with lexicase selection.

This project also investigated the application of several of the new techniques that it developed, such as UMAD and lexicase selection, to other forms of machine learning, showing that they can improve learning in deep neural networks and in hybrid classical-quantum reinforcement learning systems. It also showed how ideas from other areas of machine learning, such as transfer learning (in which the results of prior learning episodes help to solve new problems) can be applied to evolutionary computation.

The technologies developed in this project have the potential for broad impacts on science and society because they enhance the power of widely-applicable problem-solving methods, and because the enhanced technologies have been disseminated in open-source software systems. The project also had educational impacts. It was conducted primarily at an undergraduate institution with a curriculum based on independent student research, in conjunction with a top-ranked computer science Ph.D. program at a consortial partner institution. The project included educational activities that integrated research and education across undergraduate and graduate levels, and produced publications with undergraduate and graduate student co-authors.
